questions: How do the early attempts to classify the chemical elements differ from the modern attempt ? Which of the two is better and why ? Give examples.
answers: The early attempts to classify elements were made on the basis of atomic masses of the elements. Modern basis is the atomic number. This is better because now it is established that atomic number of an element is the fundamental property. Further there are certain anomalies in Mendeleev’s periodic table such as the position of isotopes and misplacements of certain elements, e.g. Argon is placed  before potassium in Mendeleev’s periodic table .

questions: What are metalloids ? How many electrons can be present in the valency shell of their atoms ? In what part of the periodic table these are located ? What type of oxide are formed by these elements ?
answers: Metalloids are elements which resemble both metals and non-metals. The valency shell of metalloids contain 3, 4, 5, 6 elements starting from periods 2 to 5 respectively. They are found on the right side of the table in the zig-zag column, e.g., boron, silicon, germanium, arsenic etc. They form amphoteric oxides.

questions: An element ‘X’ is liquid, non-metallic. Can you predict its position in the periodic table ?
answers: As the element ‘X’ is non-metallic, it may be belonging to group 17. In group 17, first two elements are gases. Metallic character of elements  increases on moving down the group. Therefore, the element ‘X’ may be located in group 17 and 3rd or 4th period of the periodic table.

questions: Given below are the melting points and atomic radii of three elements X, Y and Z of the periodic table having ‘n’ electrons in the outermost shells of their atoms — Melting point  Atomic radii  State four inference that can be drawn about the elements on the basis of the above data.
answers: Since each element contains the same number of valence electrons, n in the outermost shells of their atoms, therefore X, Y and Z, belong to the same group.  The atomic radii increase from X to Z so metallic character increases from X towards Z.  X, Y and Z have melting points above 25°C . Therefore X, Y and Z are solid at room temperature.  The ionization potential decreases from X to Z because they belong to the same group in the descending order.
